message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest pericarditis. Colchicine has shown to help prevent recurrence of pericarditis. Aspirin and ibuprofen can help with pain but do not prevent recurrence, and systemic antibiotics are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest pericarditis, and colchicine is a first-line treatment for preventing recurrence of idiopathic recurrent pericarditis. Aspirin and ibuprofen can help alleviate symptoms but are not preventive measures. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated unless there is suspicion of an underlying infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with acute pericarditis, and colchicine is the drug of choice to prevent recurrence. Aspirin and ibuprofen can be used for pain relief, but they do not prevent recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated since the cause of the pericarditis is not infectious.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and a friction rub suggest pericarditis. Colchicine is used to prevent recurrences of pericarditis. Aspirin and ibuprofen can help alleviate the symptoms, but they do not prevent recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated as there are no signs of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The friction rub and ECG changes suggest that the patient has pericarditis. Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that can prevent recurrence of pericarditis. Ibuprofen and aspirin can help with pain relief but will not prevent recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated as there is no evidence of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG suggest acute pericarditis. Colchicine is used to prevent recurrence of acute pericarditis. Aspirin or NSAIDs are used to relieve pain and inflammation, but they do not prevent recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated as there is no evidence of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows a PR segment depression, which is indicative of pericarditis. Colchicine, an anti-inflammatory drug, can prevent recurrence of pericarditis. Aspirin can also reduce inflammation, but colchicine is more effective in preventing recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated for pericarditis. Ibuprofen can help with pain relief but does not prevent recurrence.

Colchicine is used to prevent recurrences of pericarditis. Ibuprofen and aspirin can help manage pain and inflammation but do not prevent recurrences. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated in this case since there is no evidence of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with symptoms of pericarditis and the ECG shows diffuse ST segment elevations. Colchicine has been shown to prevent recurrences of pericarditis. Aspirin can help relieve pain and inflammation, but it is not a preventative measure for recurrence. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated as there is no sign of infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, ECG findings and the presence of a friction rub suggest pericarditis. Colchicine is used to prevent recurrence of pericarditis. Ibuprofen and aspirin can help with the pain and inflammation but are not specific preventive measures. Systemic antibiotics are not indicated as the cause is not infective.
